articles.headline: U.K. Paid $20 Million for New Coronavirus Tests. They Didn’t Work.
articles.snippet: Facing a global scramble for materials, British officials bought millions of unproven kits from China in a gamble that became an embarrassment.
articles.abstract: Facing a global scramble for materials, British officials bought millions of unproven kits from China in a gamble that became an embarrassment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two Chinese companies were offering a risky proposition: two million home test kits said to detect antibodies for the coronavirus for at least $20 million, take it or leave it.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Jane Bradley

articles.headline: Straggling in a Good Economy, and Now Struggling in a Crisis
articles.snippet: The coronavirus pandemic has shown how close to the edge many Americans were living, with pay and benefits eroding even as corporate profits surged.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus pandemic has shown how close to the edge many Americans were living, with pay and benefits eroding even as corporate profits surged.
articles.lead_paragraph: An indelible image from the Great Depression features a well-dressed family seated with their dog in a comfy car, smiling down from an oversize billboard on weary souls standing in line at a relief agency. “World’s highest standard of living,” the billboard boasts, followed by a tagline: “There’s no way like the American Way.”

articles.headline: Trump Says States Can Start Reopening While Acknowledging the Decision Is Theirs
articles.snippet: The guidelines released by the president effectively mean that any restoration of American society will take place on a patchwork basis.
articles.abstract: The guidelines released by the president effectively mean that any restoration of American society will take place on a patchwork basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump told the nation’s governors on Thursday that they could begin reopening businesses, restaurants and other elements of daily life by May 1 or earlier if they wanted to, but abandoned his threat to use what he had claimed was his absolute authority to impose his will on them.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: China’s Economy Shrinks, Ending a Nearly Half-Century of Growth
articles.snippet: The contraction comes at a time when the rest of the world needs an economic boost, underscoring how momentous the task of reviving the global economy will be.
articles.abstract: The contraction comes at a time when the rest of the world needs an economic boost, underscoring how momentous the task of reviving the global economy will be.

articles.headline: Bill Gates, at Odds With Trump on Virus, Becomes a Right-Wing Target
articles.snippet: The Microsoft co-founder turned philanthropist has been attacked with falsehoods that he created the coronavirus and wants to profit from it.
articles.abstract: The Microsoft co-founder turned philanthropist has been attacked with falsehoods that he created the coronavirus and wants to profit from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a 2015 speech, Bill Gates warned that the greatest risk to humanity was not nuclear war but an infectious virus that could threaten the lives of millions of people.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Davey Alba and Marc Tracy

articles.headline: When Even Amazon Is Sold Out of Exploding Kittens
articles.snippet: Sometimes products are in stock. Sometimes they aren’t. And delivery times vary widely. A virus-fueled surge in orders has created chaos behind the scenes, and confusion for customers.
articles.abstract: Sometimes products are in stock. Sometimes they aren’t. And delivery times vary widely. A virus-fueled surge in orders has created chaos behind the scenes, and confusion for customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Exploding Kittens, a game that bills itself as “a kitty-powered version of Russian roulette,” spent years ranked as one of the most popular card games on Amazon’s store. When the coronavirus pandemic hit, sales doubled week after week, as families looked for distraction while hunkering down.

articles.headline: Why We Don’t Know the True Death Rate for Covid-19
articles.snippet: Determining what percentage of those infected by the coronavirus will die is a key question for epidemiologists, but an elusive one during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Determining what percentage of those infected by the coronavirus will die is a key question for epidemiologists, but an elusive one during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Coroners in some parts of the country are overwhelmed. Funeral homes in coronavirus hot spots can barely keep up. Newspaper obituary pages in hard-hit areas go on and on. Covid-19 is on track to kill far more people in the United States this year than the seasonal flu.

articles.headline: France Weighs Its Love of Liberty in Fight Against Coronavirus
articles.snippet: The French are cautiously considering digital tracking, which has proved effective in Asia. But can a country that so prizes personal freedom and privacy ever accept it?
articles.abstract: The French are cautiously considering digital tracking, which has proved effective in Asia. But can a country that so prizes personal freedom and privacy ever accept it?
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As France sought clues last month on how to tame the coronavirus, experts looked at one tool that has been central to the strategy of some Asian nations: digital tracking. Citing threats to “individual liberties,” the powerful interior minister dismissed it as alien to “French culture.”
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut

articles.headline: Uber and Lyft Are Searching for Lifelines
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing competitors started the year with optimism. Now, like most other companies, they’re trying to survive the cratering economy.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing competitors started the year with optimism. Now, like most other companies, they’re trying to survive the cratering economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — After Seattle became the first major city in the United States to experience a widespread coronavirus outbreak in March, Uber’s business there plunged between 60 and 70 percent, the company’s chief executive said.
